Basic Analysis

Read in Clean Data

df <- read_rds("data-processed/01-storm-data.rds")

Answering Questions

Which storm types cause the most damage?

#filter for only events that have damage values for property
damages_property <- df |> filter((!is.na(damage_val_prop)))

damages_property
# A tibble: 77,303 × 12
   EVENT_TYPE    INJURIES_DIRECT INJURIES_INDIRECT DEATHS_DIRECT DEATHS_INDIRECT
   <chr>                   <dbl>             <dbl>         <dbl>           <dbl>
 1 Thunderstorm…               0                 0             0               0
 2 Thunderstorm…               0                 0             0               0
 3 Hail                        0                 0             0               0
 4 Thunderstorm…               0                 0             0               0
 5 Thunderstorm…               1                 0             0               0
 6 Thunderstorm…               0                 0             0               0
 7 Thunderstorm…               0                 0             0               0
 8 Tornado                     0                 0             0               0
 9 Thunderstorm…               0                 0             0               0
10 Thunderstorm…               0                 0             0               0
# ℹ 77,293 more rows
# ℹ 7 more variables: CZ_TYPE <chr>, CZ_FIPS <dbl>, CZ_NAME <chr>,
#   damage_val_prop <dbl>, damage_val_crop <dbl>, begin_date <date>,
#   end_date <date>
#now groupby event type and sum up damages
most_damage_property <- damages_property |> group_by(EVENT_TYPE) |> 
  summarize(total_damage_property = sum(damage_val_prop)) |> 
  arrange(total_damage_property |> desc())

most_damage_property
# A tibble: 41 × 2
   EVENT_TYPE          total_damage_property
   <chr>                               <dbl>
 1 Flash Flood                   48236907050
 2 Hail                          11875746180
 3 Storm Surge/Tide               9903555740
 4 Tropical Storm                 9280792000
 5 Hurricane (Typhoon)            8123480300
 6 Hurricane                      6093380000
 7 Tornado                        3717989770
 8 Thunderstorm Wind              1086976030
 9 Flood                          1022139200
10 Drought                        1012652000
# ℹ 31 more rows

Flash Floods caused the most damage to property in Texas since 2000, totaling over $48 billion in damage. Hail was the second most damaging event type with $11.8 billion in damage.

damages_crops <- df |> filter((!is.na(damage_val_crop)))

damages_crops
# A tibble: 72,323 × 12
   EVENT_TYPE    INJURIES_DIRECT INJURIES_INDIRECT DEATHS_DIRECT DEATHS_INDIRECT
   <chr>                   <dbl>             <dbl>         <dbl>           <dbl>
 1 Hail                        0                 0             0               0
 2 Thunderstorm…               0                 0             0               0
 3 Thunderstorm…               0                 0             0               0
 4 Thunderstorm…               0                 0             0               0
 5 Tornado                     0                 0             0               0
 6 Hail                        0                 0             0               0
 7 Tornado                     0                 0             0               0
 8 Thunderstorm…               0                 0             0               0
 9 Thunderstorm…               0                 0             0               0
10 Thunderstorm…               0                 0             0               0
# ℹ 72,313 more rows
# ℹ 7 more variables: CZ_TYPE <chr>, CZ_FIPS <dbl>, CZ_NAME <chr>,
#   damage_val_prop <dbl>, damage_val_crop <dbl>, begin_date <date>,
#   end_date <date>
most_damage_crop <- damages_crops |> group_by(EVENT_TYPE) |> 
  summarize(total_damage_crop = sum(damage_val_crop)) |> 
  arrange(total_damage_crop |> desc())

most_damage_crop
# A tibble: 40 × 2
   EVENT_TYPE     total_damage_crop
   <chr>                      <dbl>
 1 Drought              9915104000 
 2 Flash Flood           520403186.
 3 Hail                  479212406.
 4 Frost/Freeze          471010000 
 5 Flood                 411104400 
 6 Wildfire              166401405 
 7 Hurricane              99700000 
 8 Tornado                77024992.
 9 Tropical Storm         60240000 
10 Heavy Rain             59181560 
# ℹ 30 more rows

Droughts caused the most damage to crops in Texas out of all severe weather events with $9.9 billion of damage.

Where did the most damaging storms occur?

What year had the most damages?

yr_damage_prop <- damages_property |> group_by(year(begin_date)) |> 
  summarize(total_damage_prop = sum(damage_val_prop)) |> 
  arrange(total_damage_prop |> desc())

yr_damage_crop <- damages_crops |> group_by(year(begin_date)) |> 
  summarize(total_damage_crop = sum(damage_val_crop)) |> 
  arrange(total_damage_crop |> desc())

yr_damage_prop
# A tibble: 24 × 2
   `year(begin_date)` total_damage_prop
                <dbl>             <dbl>
 1               2017       51526434600
 2               2008       16222067700
 3               2001        5511937800
 4               2016        3609540800
 5               2019        3092756900

 7               2005        2434667250
 8               2012        2235932710
 9               2023        2185371800
10               2015        2142740070
# ℹ 14 more rows
yr_damage_crop
# A tibble: 24 × 2
   `year(begin_date)` total_damage_crop
                <dbl>             <dbl>

# ℹ 14 more rows

How have the damages from storm events changed over time?

ggplot(
  damages_property,
  aes(x = begin_date, y = damage_val_prop)
) +
  geom_point()

ggplot(
  damages_crops,
  aes(x = begin_date, y = damage_val_crop)
) +
  geom_point()
